author: Domidod1d

description.text:
Update: Do not plug that model relay (shown) directly into the Ramps D8 port. After being energized for about 3 seconds, it makes a sound not unlike gunfire and shoots some kind of brown fuzzy stuff all over.

Box for a Prusa i3 printer heatbed relay. Most don't require an external relay but in some instances, connecting the heatbed directly to the power supply works better.

The bottom of the box has offsets to allow the solder connections on the bottom of the relay board to hang so the board lays flat.

The cover doesn't snap down. I didn't have enough patience to add screw holes through the bottom and snap-in-place cover so the Sketchup file is included for modifications.

title: Ultra light x-axis for custom 3D printer

description.text:
I am always developing my printer, trying to make it better. The newest adittion to the design is a light x-axis.
The extruder is removed from the moving x-axis and placed on the frame. The design is made for pneumatic fittings.
I use a bowden geared extruder to feed the hot end:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60531 Only the hot end is now moving, making higher printing speeds possible. The quick fit design for the j-head is derived from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30951
Printed with 30% infill.

This is a box for mounting a Home Depot power switch on the Y axis 10mm rods.

The switch is a Servalite TA201U rocker switch, SPST.

Mounts are borrowed from--
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335726

Make sure to solder the wires before snapping the switch into place. The box doesn't open for access inside.

Print with supports or the mounting clips will fail. I used overhang supports generated by Meshmixer.

Note: The photos show the C clips in the wrong position. They have been moved down in the STL file to the other edge of the box so the box doesn't lift the bed up.

author: joseph_terzian

description.text:
Printed at 0.2mm layer height with 50% infill for rigidity. Needs supports to print.

I found in my XYZprinting DaVinci 1.0 printer that if the Z-Axis lead screw hung free from the build table, that it would not point directly to the shaft coming from the Z-Axis stepper motor. Thus meaning there was a missalignment with the location of the Z-Axis stepper motor and the Z-Axis lead screw. So I designed this replacement mount with slots for Left-to-Right adjustment and Front-to-back adjustment to help position the motor directly under the free hanging lead screw. Now the lead screw is almost perfectly vertical and my print quality has improved (Z-wobble reduced).

Works with the screw already on the printer for the stock Z-Axis motor mount.

I also noticed on the stock motor mount that when the lead screw would spin, there was wobble coming from the motor itself. It reveals itself by pulling up on the motor mounting bracket in an orbital fashion as the lead screw spins. I believe that I have a bent shaft coming from the stepper. This may be remedied by changing the rigid coupling to a flexible coupling to lessen the affect that the wobble from the motor has on the printing part. Replacing the motor may also help.

INSTALLATION:

WARNING: Always power off machine before performing any work on it to prevent electrical shock.

ATTENTION: I am a mechanical engineer by trade and this is second nature to me. So I've tried to make the instructions easy and thorough. However, if you are not comfortable with the task, do not start what you don't think you'll be able to finish. I am not responsible for you not being able to put your printer back together.

NOTE: I have only tested this on the DaVinci 1.0 printer. It may work on their other models, but I can't guarantee it.

  1. Jog the table on the Z-Axis to about 1/2 to 2/3 of the height from the bottom of the printer. Now power off the printer.

  2. Using a 1/16" Hex Allen Wrench loosen (but do not remove) the lowest two set screws in the coupling from the Z-Axis Stepper motor drive shaft.

  3. Using a Torx T10 driver, remove the four screws from the top of the mounting bracket that attach to the motor. Set aside.

  4. Using a Torx T10 driver, remove the two screws (1 on each side) that secure the mounting bracket to the printer base. Set aside but keep separate from the previous 4 screws as these 2 are longer.

  5. CAREFULLY lift up and hold the build table with your hand so that the coupling (still attached to the Z-Axis lead screw) comes free of the motor shaft.

  6. While the coupling is separate from the motor shaft, remove the stock metal mounting bracket and replace with the 3D printed model.

  7. Lower the table by hand and guide the coupling back over the motor shaft.

  8. Tighten the set screws on the coupling back against the motor shaft.

  9. Re-install the 4 screws through the top of the new motor mount into the motor BUT LEAVE LOOSE.

  10. Re-install the 2 screws (1 on each side) that hold the mount to the machine base BUT LEAVE LOOSE.

  11. BY HAND, hold the motor in its new desired location while tightening all screws. DO NOT OVER-TIGHTEN or they will crush the plastic. Review the pictures for reference of finished product.

  12. Turn the printer back on and use the jog function for the Z-Axis to move it up and down a couple times. Make sure that the new position holds and that the plastic motor mount is rigid enough.

  13. Pat yourself on the back and show someone the cool thing you just did!

comments.text: thank you for the awesome file and instructions...I will be trying this soon.... I have a 2.0 and the z is fine but my new 1.0 PRO has this wobble...
comments.author: laserrr

comments.text: Thank you, laserrr.  Good luck!  I think part of the layer wobble is also related to the feed gear in the extruder head not being concentric.  I noticed that the "wobble" pattern changes frequency (layers/pattern-repeat) depending on the size of the print.  For instance, if I print a series of rings with varying diameters and then hold the edges up to one another the "wobble" pattern does not mesh 100% (Note: you have to print the rings 1 at a time for this study).  If you still have a problem after you use this motor mount, then you may have the same problem.  I haven't come up with a fix for that yet, unfortunately.
comments.author: laserrr

title: Honda Ruckus battery box geometric plate

description.text: I replaced my Ruckus headlights with an LED bar and wanted the front end to be a little less bare than the plain battery box. This part fits between the headlight mount holes perfectly and looks like something or other, I dunno. I just wanted to remove some unused space.

I printed in ABS at 20% infill and treated the finished product with a layer or two of bondo spot putty. Primed then painted with krylon textured. I spaced it one m5 flat washer's width so the paint couldn't bond to the battery box (Its ABS as well, BTW).

title: Cover lid for Thermos 40oz cup cap

description.text:
I wanted to make a cover for my cup so dust wouldn't fall into it. Thermos didn't make one, so I did.

Note that it needs to be printed in a PETT material to truly be considered 'food grade'

I printed mine with a very dense infill and I haven't tried it with hot liquid yet. I ended up backing down from 70% to 50%. I figure the heat of the liquid could deform the lid, so we'll see... The one pictured was printed in purple PLA on a Rostock MAX V2. I used Repetier-Host and Slic3r 1.2.9.

Note that it needs to be printed in a PETT material to truly be considered 'food grade'

I'll include my modified slice settings in the downloads as a reference (but they're for PLA).

author: Vitsika

description.text:
Assembly video: https://vid.me/Kwxf

Ribbon cable version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1107461

Ever wish you could have some nice orderly data cables for your arduino projects without paying a surprisingly large amount for crimpers, sockets, and pins? This isn't the perfect solution, and you have to do some soldering and gluing, but it is probably the cheapest if you repurpose spare cables of one sort or another.

All you need are some cheap male (for plugs) or famale (for sockets) headers like these:
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/116 / https://www.sparkfun.com/products/115
https://www.adafruit.com/products/392 / https://www.adafruit.com/products/598

These look cool and will save xacto-ing female headers, but I don't have any: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/743

Then print out a shell to accommodate as many or as few pins as you want in either a single or double column format, with or without a strain relief shell. After that, solder up your wires, superglue the shell in place (liquid superglue on the header after insertion into shell (seeps into crevices), gel superglue between plug shell and strain relief shell), and voila -- data cable. It has an (optional, default) indicator bump so you can keep track of the correct orientation.

To use this, either download the openScad file and edit the variables in openScad, or use the "open in customizer" button in the right hand column of this page.

Printing with a brim is definitely recommended. Photos show mostly ABS (there is one clear PLA shell) and printed on a Lulzbot Mini. ABS is more forgiving, PLA requires more tweaking and closer tolerances because of its rigidity.

Potential Cura Issue: You can print with or without divider walls between the pins. I found that with my printer, Cura (lulzbot edition, version 14.09, OSX) would not print the divider walls -- they are a single nozzle width (0.5 mm in my case, adjustable to your printer of course). However, slic3r with pronterface to rescue -- that software prints out the divider walls like a champ.

PS: This is my first involved (for me at least) openScad project, and I'd really like to become somewhat proficient at using openScad. I'm also not a professional coder so hints, tips, and criticisms with corrections or examples would be deeply appreciated.

comments.text: This is brilliant. I'm thinking about using it for an Arduino Mega to breakout all the pins. It looks like the angle on the strain relief shell might be pretty sharp for the long double-row header. Maybe that's just how it looks to me in Customizer. What do you think?
comments.author: I_Makes_Tuff

comments.text: Thanks for the kind comments.  There is a variable named "cableRadius" that lets you adjust the size of the round hole on the end of the strain relief shell (I think it is on a separate tab in Customizer).  So if you have some fat cable bundle that's 10mm across, just change that to 5mm (it's a radius, not a diameter).  With fat cables this can make the shell kind of stubby looking, but you can adjust the height of the shell too with the "strainHeight" variable.  All measurements are in mm.

title: SHARKZ... Fun Multipurpose Clips / Holders / Pegs with moving jaws that bite!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Fun one piece print that can be used for a variety of purposes from holding notes to keeping bags closed and even as pegs for your clothes line (Refer to images).

This is a quick and easy print (as long as your machine does bridges reasonably well) that will come off the build plate ready to bite... refer to the instructions for print details.

Also check out my other similar designs:

'Bugz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1904654

'Minisaurs' https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476792

'Z-REX' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1594269

'Ratz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1532944

'Crocz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:941177

'Woodpeckerz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1155168

'Eaglez' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:963892

'Catz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:988088

'Scorpionz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001286

Note: If you like these check out the rest of my designs!

On a Replicator 2 SHARKZ print really well with Raft / Standard 0.20mm Resolution / 4 Shells / 60% infill. No Support.

Using 4 shells and 60% (+) infill makes the SHARKZ strong and ensures a good bite... you can use less shells and less infill but they will be less springy so the bite strength is reduced. SHARKZ should have a strong bite!

comments.text: Tweaking things always changes other things however you can do a number of things yourself... I'm not sure how many shells (outer layers) you got up to but use 4 or 5 as that can help. You may also want to try different infill patterns (like Linear). Scaling it up uniformly a small amount will also help as it adds thickness without affecting the relationship between parts.
comments.author: ThomF

comments.text: Thanks for your suggestions. However, my issue isn't that the teeth aren't closely joined in the build. They are. The problem is that the clamping force is very modest. I was hoping for something more like that of a clothes pin which would clamp down on anything placed between the jaws. Things seem to slide out far too easily.
comments.author: muzz64

comments.text: Thanks for your helpful explanations on this.
comments.author: ThomF

comments.text: Even thickening the spring area up a bit wouldn't make a significant difference overall... the real issue is PLA weakens with use and also adapts the different positions within a relatively small amount of time... particularly if there is any warmth. They work okay as pegs but the jaws will ultimately settle in the position they have been sitting in when clamped on. That makes it the new neutral point... no longer with the jaws closed. With PLA the only real solution is to add springs etc.

Acts as a spacer for the wall panels of a Leapfrog Creatr; prevents bending of the panel and allows one to tighten down the screws completely. Especially useful for the front panel -- on my printer it was slanted when screwed on.

The positioning of the hole may need work.

Used 123D Design from Autodesk.
I measured the space using a digital micrometer and replicated it in 123D Design. It is 2.5mm thick, which was ideal to fix the slanting of the front panel as mentioned.

Here is my “5 Buck Boat”. I decided to start with a known quantity of coinage. So, in this case 20 US quarters totaling 5 bucks.

I had to design/build this twice (see pictures). But, the first attempt highlighted two things. One, I underestimated the amount of displaced water needed. And two, I was storing my coins too high creating balance issues.

So, my second attempt was much better. Just enough displacement to store the 5 bucks. Once I was solid on floating the coins I added a deck, antennas, cabin, tire bumpers and a couple anchors.

Check out the instructions!
Thanks, Reamo

Couple things to note:

  1. Bond parts using Acetone.
  2. Print and build, no sanding, drilling or painting required.
  3. Antennas can be printed, I just found some wire (paper clip, needle, thread of material from the print head, or whatever you find works).
  4. Doors and windows colored in with Sharpie.

title: Sig Sauer 522 1 inch Cheek Riser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a Sig Sauer 522 1 inch Cheek Riser that I just designed and printed for my rifle. I needed it because I added an optic and I could not sight it solidly without a good cheek weld. It is a single piece print that prints vertically with the back side down on the build plate. It has slightly canted in clamping sides to add a firm grip on the butt stock. It just slides onto the top of the Sigs butt stock. I also hot glued on a 1/8 inch thick piece of high density foam padding for comfort. I tested it today at the range and it is perfect. I am open to suggestions or comments for improvement of the design or printability.
Print vertically with the flat back end down on the build plate. I built mine with ABS. I hot glued on a 1/8 inch thin high density black foam pad for comfort.

title: Tamiya LiPo battery holder for bathtub chassis CC01 TA01/2/3 DF01 FF01

description.text:
LiPo battery holder for Tamiya TA01/02/03, FF01, DF01, CC01 chassis with integrated LiPo monitor case

Companies like LRP sell LiPo batteries that are round and fit the bathtub chassis of old Tamiya cars. However, the batteries are about 5 mm longer than equivalent NiMH packs and therefore the standard battery holder does not fit anymore.

This part solves the issue. The holder is inserted from the top and the 3 lugs hold the battery in place. A body clip secures battery holder by being inserted in the middle lug between the battery and the chassis.

The battery lock also has an (optional) mount for the standard 1-8S LiPo monitors.

Made with OpenSCAD; source file included.

For 3D printing the part is split into two pieces:

  • Part A is most of the base plate and the LiPo monitor case
  • Part B is the battery holder

Round, thin brim pieces have been added to ensure the thin parts print well. Cut them off after printing.

ABS is the material of choice as it is flexible and strong.
Print Part A with normal settings. For Part B ensure In-Fill is set to 100% for maximum strength.

Glue the pieces together for final assembly. We used Tamiya ABS glue.

If you just need the battery holder without LiPo monitor case I included an appropriate STL file; likewise if you just want a LiPo monitor case.

comments.text:
I'm about to order this part to be printed from a local company, and I get to choose the resolution(0.1-0.4mm) and inner fill percentage(20/100%). What are the correct settings?
Thanks!
comments.author: ybaryo

comments.text:
Hi! If the cost is the same, I would go for 0.1mm resolution (I guess that's layer height) and 50% in-fill.
If prices get cheaper for larger layer heights (because that means it prints faster) than 0.25mm resolution is fine too.

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Metal Cable Strain Relief

description.text: This is a remix of Rice9300's Cable Stress Relief Holder which might I say worked incredibly well but it kept moving around and letting the cable sag, which very well could have been operator error, but I went ahead and inverted it and added a little tab so it could hold onto the side without moving. It also holds the cables leaning towards the print bed but it does a great job of keeping them off of it!
I would print at 100% infill for the strongest support but you can go as low as 50% for a little flex in the part. Also support material will be needed to print this part.

title: Printbot Simple Metal Ring Light Holder

description.text:
I needed a ring light for my Printrbot Simple Metal for those long overnight prints when I would turn all the lights out. I simply cable-tied the light onto the ring and it slides right onto the brim of the printer right in front of the induction sensor like in the pictures. I would have liked to put it below the extruder but there was no room. This one is designed for a 60MM ring light which I got off of amazon for fairly cheap

Here is the link for the lights: http://www.amazon.com/Amico-White-Angel-Light-Headlight/dp/B007Q946RQ/ref=sr_1_11?ie=UTF8&qid=1435995547&sr=8-11&keywords=60mm+ring+light&pebp=1435995561058&perid=086HHB89WH2R71Q8EHFJ
Any infill settings are fine seeing as its not a high demand part and it does not carry a lot of weight. Support material will be needed to print that arm the holds onto the printrbot.

Nothing to do with the OpenRc Truggy.. completely designed from the beginning with the idea of making a full functional and time enduring RC car with solid components found on the internet.Works GREAT on road and off road and gives you the possibility to personalize all the settings in few seconds. Loved designing/building it and hope you will enjoy it! If anyone has problems printing/building You can contact me without hesitation, I will be very glad to give a hand! Enjoy!

Additional Materials Needed:

1) Shock Absorber code. 02002 - 2 Sets
2) Diff. Main Gear code. 03004 - 1 Set
3) Motor Gear code. 03005 - 1 Set
4) Diff. Complete code. 03005 - 1 Set
5) Drive Gear Shaft code. 03015 - 2 Sets
6) Wheel Axle code. 02033 - 2 Sets
7) Universal Joint Code. 02016 - 1 Set
8) DogBones code. 02003 - 2 Sets
9) Center DogBone code. 03003 - 1 Set
10) Ball Bearing 10x5x4 code. 02139 - 1 Set
11) Ball Bearing 15x10x4 code. 02138 - 1 Set
12) Plenty Of 3mm Screws!! and some 5mm. Unable Links

These are all products of Himoto and are easily found on EBay, for me they are the best products quality/price around but you can use whichever components you prefer because they are all standard 1:10 sizes.

description.text:
Tool holder for open beam.

Useful for placing tools often used for printer maintenance.

I created some scripts to

  • create an STL from a Picture (image2stl)
  • creating a milling program from a STL (stl2gcode)
  • creating milling program from SVG (togcode)
  • creating milling program from PLT (togcode)
  • viewing milling programs (viewer)

These are coded in python based on famous clipper library.
The version used is pyclipper-0.9.3b0.
For milling i use a portal axis driven by the famous Arduino+Ramps+Marlin trio.
I can mill some piece for you if you desire.
I made these for drilling out holes in 3D printed parts.

Open in Customizer. Input the dimensions for the handle. Note that if you have drill bits measured in inches, you will need to change that at the top and then input your diameter AS A DECIMAL. Print Insert Nuts into the nut traps Insert the drill bit Insert set screws. You should be able to tighten them a lot, but do remember it is plastic. Also
It appears on my computer that there is an issue with rendering the handle in Customizer. It cuts a small chunk out of the lower groove. It only appears in Customizer, however, once you export it as an .STL, it goes away.

description.text: Shell for D-Sub type connectors, fully adjustable to your desired needs (because I've thrown in the FreeCAD files).

You will need:-

2 x M3 by 15 screws.
2 x M3 Nuts.
2 x No 2 x 9 self tapping screws.

Print the shell twice and also print the gripper block twice. Take care that your slicer settings don't over-extrude.

Trim off any roughness with a sharp scalpel.

Trial fit and trim further as needed (Hopefully not too much).

NOTE:- I printed this with an E-3D V6 hotend using the stock 0.4mm nozzle with decent results but I can't help thinking I should have used a 0.3mm nozzle. I wouldn't go smaller though.

author: frogmangeek

description.text:
Now ABS safe!

Since the success of a 3D printable Y carriage in my current design, I have been requested to modify it for an i3.

This carriage is based on design and style of my highly successful carriage. The first design survived 3 re-designs of my 3D printer and about 2 years of use. Sagging due to radiant heat was what eventually lead to it being made obsolete. As such, I improved on the design, and I am happy to announce that it is now safe to use for ABS printing.

Features
The original design has been modified to accept the i3 Y mount and raised to fit into an i3's space. It has holes in the frame for zip ties to hold down the LMU88 bearings and the necessary attachments to stop the bearings slipping.

The part has now been updated to be 10mm thick, instead of the 5mm as bases were failing over long use. You can now use 3 point stabilisation, and it also has a mount for cable chains.

Requirements
It will require 16x25mm M3 screws and nuts to attach the legs to the body, washers are recommended. Also, 3 or 4x50mm M3 screws with nuts, washers and springs to keep the heated bed off the base. A sheet of cardboard and an air gap between the heater and the carriage is essential as it will protect the carriage from the heat radiating from the heated bed.

And as with all parts for your 3D printer, ABS is the recommended material to construct this part.

You will need 2 pairs of legs and one body to every base. Bearing mounts are optional.

PS.
I have since moved on from using a plastic bed carriage and I don't plan on further development of this project. As it may help those on a shoestring budget get their first printer up and running, I'll keep this part posted and available for those interested in experimenting.

comments.text: Can I print this using abs and use heated bed to print abs?
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: I have been using my latest design to print with ABS with no problem at all, though I would HIGHLY recommend placing an insulator, like a sheet of cardboard, between the bed and the base, and using M3x50mm bolts.
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: The part has now been updated to the same standard as my current bed. My bed has survived about 3 months of printing ABS, even printing parts for itself (in ABS). Though, my recommendation of using 50mm M3 screws and a sheet of cardboard still stand.

I've recently switched over to using a homemade sidemount rig for diving. Finding no good source for the necessary backplates (or some CAD files allowing me to have some locally cut) I decided to produce my own in OpenSCAD. Initially I was planning to simply mock the plates up in ABS and then have them cut out of stainless steel, but at the current 5mm thickness printed with 100% infill I have found these plates to be sufficiently strong as is.

The design will likely evolve as I experiment with the harness; for now this is a usable configuration. If you want to recreate the stl files from the openscad simply comment/uncomment the dorsal and lumbar module calls as needed - the plates are slightly too large to print both properly on a 200mm x 200mm bed, so I had to do them one at a time.

description.text:
At long last, everyone in the world (ok everyone who has access to a 3d printer) can have their own bust of America's greatest entertainer and statesman, Stephen Colbert.  
Even better, you can use this model and your favorite 3d modeling software to add Mr. Colbert's face to objects which were formerly lacking in Colbert heads, like bannisters, umbrella handles, toothpaste squeezers, and rabbits.  (To name a few.)
Made with a Polhemus 3d scanner at the Colbert set on 6/6/2011.

"HighRes" versions are very high-res. The LowRes and LowerRes versions still have a lot of detail and are more reliable, so start with those. This bust should print well on a MakerBot Thing-O-Matic even without support material. Check out http://www.polhemus.com/ for more information about their great scanners.

title: GamePi - A retropie based portable emulator

description.text:
Hello there, retro-game loving people!

This... interesting looking thing is a portable retropie console!
With a 13.000 mAh LiPo-Battery, you can enjoy hours of playing your favourite games!

It consists of a Raspberry Pi B+ or 2 and a lot of other parts I included in the instructions manual.

Please note, that this is work in progress, I´ll will soon replace the ugly on/off switch with something more elegant, like a button...
Also are a smaller Design and a circuit board the next thing I will make and share.

Hope you enjoy it, if anyone has suggestions, pleas send me a message ;)

So, things you need to built this monster:

A 7inch Display ( a cheap one from china with driver board will do )
An amplifier with speaker ( also good from china, I used 35mm one )
An audio connector and a switch
A lipo charger board ( TP4056 or chinese board)
A big LiPo-battery, I got mine from aliexpress(73x128mm is fine)
A raspberry Pi, B+ or Pi 2
And a lot of wires, I will include schematics later

And probably some patient wouldn´t be bad ^^

author: GuardianKnight83

title: The Osprey Hand by Alderhand and e-Nable

description.text:
E-Nable and Alderhand are pleased to announce the arrival of the Osprey! The Osprey was built in Blender based on the low-poly interior and robust components of the original Raptor Hand, but now sports an attractive fairing and a very durable and comfortable low-profile universal-fit bracer.
The osprey (Pandion haliaetus), sometimes known as the fish eagle, sea hawk, river hawk, or fish hawk, is a diurnal, fish-eating bird of prey. (Wikipedia)
This device was named the Osprey because it is a Raptor, but optimized for the use of heavy gauge nylon monofilament, most widely available as fishing line. The large mono has excellent Bowden properties, so the cables are pulled to provide flexion and pushed to provide extension. This device requires neither elastics nor springs nor any mechanical extension system.
Heavy gauge nylon monofilament is an excellent cabling material. It is generally inexpensive, and available as landscapers' trimmer line, nylon or Bridge nylon 3d printer filament, and as deep sea fishing leader line. Running through joints, it doesn't abrade at all, so there's no "sawing" of printed plastic. Nylon is very strong, so it is rarely a point of failure for mechanical devices. But probably its greatest quality is its resistance to linear compression, so it pushes as well as pulls, like the bicycle cabling used to change gears.
Elastic resistance is a major drawback to many assistive devices, because resistance reduces a device's grip strength. Furthermore, as an elastic-extended device approaches full actuation, resistance from elastics increases, so that it may be quite difficult for a user to grasp small objects. Designs which reduce or eliminate elastic resistance are a welcome development.
Pay particular attention to the new bill of materials. The Cyborg Beast, the original Raptor and the Raptor Reloaded hardware kits are not compatible with the Osprey. However, the Osprey does use the same hardware as the Gamma Raptor. Materials kits and tool kits should be available in the near future, so stay tuned.
In this version:
Elastic-free Bowden cable design; enclosed channels provide enhanced cable control
Vestigial dorsal extension channels can now be used for knuckle vise, other secondary tools, or electronics.
Fairing has a new aesthetic.
Pin-and-Proximal sets to manage tolerances ("A" is loosest; "D" is tightest)
Very durable low-profile universal fit bracer(gauntlet)

Update 2015-7-14
Palm v.2.1 The thumb has been rotated to better oppose the fingers. This affected the palm stencil, which was also updated.

Update 2015-8-26
Support material was removed from proximal phalanges. Let me know if you miss it. The hinge on the distals was bulked up, since it was a common point of failure under heavy lifting.

Update 2015-9-16
I added a new bracer/gauntlet. This fits the Osprey aesthetic better, and it has easier-to-remove support material. The old bracer will probably become part of the Gamma Raptor design.

Update 2015-11-23
Updated bracer and palm, and removed the old versions. Added 3/4" triglide buckle. Added proximal "key" to help determine which proximal tolerance best fits in the palm.

Update 2016-6-16 Instructions have improved a lot, so please have a look.
Replaced proximal and distal phalanges: improved mechanical performance.

Update 2017-10-19
Added a printable bracer stencil that will fit most clients just fine. After fitting, any overlapping leather can be trimmed if needed, but on most clients that won't be necessary.
Added sets of snap pins that are more compatible with PLA. The original pins were calculated for ABS, which is softer. So they were pretty difficult to insert in PLA builds. These PLA pins have longer tines that bend better.
Added D-Ring buckle. This is a good secure closure for the loose-weave nylon webbing.

2017-10-23
Added pin tongs and a pin pusher, to help with the insertion and removal of snap pins.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xbfhPYKO-4hcpnAmYpvGPY-vzPpO1QTiwvFZkcN3034/edit?usp=sharing

Instructions are improved continuously, so go back often.

This assembly video provides a brief look at the assembly process:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_SWHmAPipcI&index=9&list=PLBHsuyNYSpxvS1EgMP67EszQwgE-Hqq5o

comments.text: Detailed instructions are linked under Thing Details. The Google document has everything you need to know. For ABS, i'd suggest 0.2-0.3mm layers, with a brim but no support. Nozzle temp 248C bed temp 95C and no fan, or at most 25%. Then after basic post-print cleanup, use acetone vapor to smooth off the prints. Please do look at the instructions for guidance, especially if you're making an Osprey hand to fit a person.
comments.author: VPassamai

comments.text: So we need to print out every single file correct?

No, don't print everything.
Once you have determined proper print scale, print the palm (left or right) and the OSPproximalABCDKey. Then use the key to determine which letter (A, B, C, or D) represents the best mechanical tolerance for your circumstance. Then print 5 proximals of that letter and one set of pins of that letter. Print everything else at the same scale, except for the triglides. Select the triglide that corresponds with the width of nylon strap you are using and print two, at 100% scale.
I hope this helps.
What are the holes for on the white part of the hand that are on the top for ?
comments.author: zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz

comments.text: If you look at the photos you will see there is some metal hardware. Flat headed screws attach the leather and the straps. And set screws secure the cables. Two screws on each cable, for a secure connection. The screws bite directly into the plastic.
comments.author: zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz

comments.text: how do you clean out the wire holes when printed with support material
comments.author: HELIflipper03

comments.text:
As per the instructions, print with no support material. In your slicer settings, support should be turned off.
These models all have built-in support, which breaks off easily after printing. If you're printing in ABS, you may want to add some brim (if your slicer supports it) but in PLA, these components should all print great with neither brim nor support.
If you have support material in the long channels of the bracer, you can drill them out with a long drill bit. If you have support material in the curved channels of the palm, you had better just re-print that component without support.
If it were me, I'd reprint everything (except the pins) with no support. Otherwise, you will spend too much time removing support material.
comments.author: HELIflipper03

comments.author: profbink

comments.text: I'm not sure why you're unable to print the palm. Maybe your nozzle temps are too high, so you're getting too much slumping. All the components have printed successfully at scales between 100% and 200% on a variety of printers. I would suggest fiddling with your printer settings.
comments.author: thedoktorj

comments.text:
I probably should have updated. I have a number of problems with my printer that were making this unprintable. A combination of warped glass on my heated build platform, an issue with my z-axis couplers slowly sliding off the motors, and play on the y-axis seem to be the main causes. I am in the process of replacing my bed with an aluminum one and silicon heater, and then I'm gonna replace my z-axis couplers, and install a y-belt tensioner, after that I don't expect it will continue to be a problem.
p.s. Sorry for the deleted comments, Thingiverse gives me no indication that clicking the, "Post Comment" button actually works, so I hit it multiple times, when nothing seemed to be happening.
comments.author: profbink

comments.text: That's the dirty little secret about consumer 3d printers. They are temperamental and may often need adjustment and repair.
comments.author: thedoktorj

comments.text: Very true, but that's part of what makes the hobby fun, at least to me.

Hello there, retro-gaming loving people!

You don´t want to just sit and burn in the sun?
Then try the GamePi! A retropie-based mobile gaming console for all the old games we like and love, the battery is so big, you can play for hours!
With an built-in speaker and an optional audio-jack, you can play wherever you want and hear your favourite character dying!
The built-in lipo charger allows you to charge the battery wherever you are, which means you don´t have to stop playing!

It´s super-easy to print and uses screws to fit together, so you can dissasemble it easily!

The current circuit design includes a 5v Step-Up booster which gets activated by a small switch over a relay. I´m planning using a MOSFET and designing a circuit board for making it smaller.

As soon as I have that, I´ll share it to the community ;)

The full project can be found at:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:910462

Please notice that this project is still WorkInProgress, the design and efficiency of the electronics will change, I´ll make it smaller, lighter and even more good-looking!
And of course, share the files!

At a hot day in summer, I thought about, what I could do, I want to sit outside, but with this big SNES console, I would have to take a big TV and a generator with me... so what to do?

So I designed the GamePi, with the big battery, I can play for hours, outside & inside, even at driving..., but don´t do that!

It has never been easier to have all consoles and a big screen with you, wasn´t it?

So, fire up your printer, and fight against the heat!

The full project can be found at:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:910462

Vuitton earing. Fashion for fun

This is a simple extruder I made for 1.75mm filament. The only things you need to complete is an insert for motor shaft and a 8 x 11 x 7mm Bearing and some 3mm screws. It will fit a Nema 17 Stepper Motor and the famous chineese extruder. (the black one that you easily find on eBay) Enjoy ! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sRRu5mCk6TQ&feature=youtu.be
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5AlZcp0Gpig

3D Print the two portions and squeeze the Extruder and the Bearing between. Screw it to the Stepper Motor and add 2 screws each sides of the extruder. Add one screw to the center of the bearing. (5) screws total.

description.text:
This is a work in progress. All files will be uploaded later. The robot is a design of my own any ideas on how to make it look better are welcome :) The parts are designed and exported to stl using SolidWorks. The robot has its own website http://howme.net , but it is still under major changes. These are the printable parts (at their current state) of my robot. This is its third version. All parts are designed to fit with a cheap MG995 servos. They are standard servo sizes so most servo machines may match (if the design works as I expect I am planing to supply it with better servos). The whole robot is powered by 15 servo machines. The head is equipped with a wireless pinhole camera, laser, Sharp infrared sensor, two microphones in its ears (there is a room for pre-amp), a place for a RGB diode as a nose, at the top there is a place for a motion sensor.
(*The Bill of materials with links will be updated later.) I was running all servos using Arduino Mega, but I am switching to FEZ Panda II. The board should be placed at the back. The body is shallow and may contain small electronics or something else. The arms are designed to fit solar panels from a solar phone charger or similar.
The Front is designed to hold a 16x2 display (to be designed with a holder).
There should be a room for a speaker as I have added text to speech board to the system. The robot is designed to be a Johnnie 5 type so I am planning to add caterpillar tracks found here on thingiverse, but yet have to design the body that will hold the batteries and the tracks. The robot is equipped with double reduction gear (each for every track) and being controlled by a motor driver. The software can be tracked here (it is also under progress) : http://code.google.com/p/howme/ Update
There is a base with tracked links. Checkout the last image, but the problem is the body can be optimized because it takes too much material and I had to print it more then 12 hours. It should hold the reduction gear for the tracks and two packs of batteries. I hope the batteries are heavy enough to make it stable when moving around.
Print the parts and join them using servos and bolts. You can fit the servo horns using hot glue.

comments.text: This model is not really suited for 3D-printing. It's huge and has lot of oblique planes that come out jagged when printed with an FDM printer, requiring extra finishing work, that could easily be avoided by changing the design. The base is hollow and requires support structures. The plugs in the arms that go into the base are not level with either of the sides of the arm and thus also require support structures. Making two arms also makes the design complex, as one well structured arm could replace the twin design and nearly half the required printing time and material. The part on which the headphones rest against is not really needed.

title: 4th of July American Flag Coozie - Pencil/Sharpie Holder

description.text:
Happy 4th of July!

(Test print complete!)

Fits most standard US cans. Also works great as a pencil or pen holder.

UPDATE: Added a new version that has the stars and white stripes indented making it easier to color the red and blue without messing up the white!

Canned beer (or soda) is American for sure:
http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/first-canned-beer-goes-on-sale

Canned beer is making/made a comeback: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/02/beer-cans-craft_n_3536715.html

Keep it cool and ...

Please print responsibly.

Quick video to see it 360: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dGtyzxtnuKE

Printed it in white PLA with 0.4 layers and 5% fill and it took about ~3 hours on an old Makerbot Replicator Dual.

Colored it with a blue and red sharpie (Actually they were Bic Mark It permanent markers) and then popped a drink in and got busy enjoying the rest of the BBQ. (All day slow cooking/smoking left time for some quick modeling)

Daydreaming in geometry class a lifetime ago, I realized the "3 points define a circle" principle could be used equally to measure an arc's radius. I mentally designed the tool presented here, but had no way to actually build it ... until 3D printing.

Touch the tool's 3 disks to a curved surface, and read the radius in centimeters or inches on the dial.

This is a cousin of the "lens clock" your optometrist uses to measure the curvature of a lens.

Update 2015-08-01: Thank you [email protected] for text() tip; posting updated code. Also strengthened hinge, since I had one break.

Update 2016-05-29: Added "inch" version.

Print the stationary part in white, and the moving part in a contrasting color. Default print settings are fine.

Touch the numbers and tick marks with a Sharpie so they're readable against the white background.

Snap the two parts together, and it's ready to use.

description.text: Gives the car a Great and Futuristic Look!!

author: VincentMarcello

title: Ocarina - Not Quite Tuned or Playable

description.text:
OKAY, NOT QUITE TUNED, ONLY SORTA PLAYABLE.

Inspired by the linked ocarina, which is delightfully printable but not tuned to any particular scale. These two ocarinas were designed to (hopefully) play in tune. Each covers an octave and a half, including sharps and flats, per the same fingering chart which you can download.

The "alto" ocarina should run from A4 = 440Hz through F6. The "soprano" should run an octave higher, from A5 = 880Hz through F7.

I designed this using a genetic algorithm and the equation for a Helmholtz resonator, and posted the STL so people could test it out while I was on the road. I've since gotten home and printed one, and it's not bad considering: the first few notes are in tune, but only if you blow fairly hard. The higher notes are progressively flat. I'll have to do some experiments to see what went wrong.

Standard settings should work: 1 shell, 10% fill.

The dimensions matter, though, so use a layer height of 0.1mm. Also, if your printer isn't dimensionally accurate, scale accordingly. The dimensions of the "alto" ocarina should be 31.5 x 63.35 x 163.05 mm (to the nearest 0.1 mm). The dimensions of the "soprano" oc should be 26.8 x 52.6 x 99.0 mm, to the nearest 0.1 mm.

No raft or supports should be needed. You can see a built-in support; orient the oc so that that side is lying flat on the build platform.

This model is pathetic.
It makes no sound at all.
Dont waste your time.
comments.author: Zetrical

comments.text: I'm sorry that you didn't read the description or comments before printing it, so you didn't realize the design is flawed, that it has poor sound, and that the Helmholz equations are apparently inadequate for tuning an oc.
comments.author: Zetrical

comments.text: Sorry for the negativity, but like I said, I was excited.
comments.author: budney

comments.text: Finally fixed me printer and got this printed (the soprano). The first few notes I can hit, but anything higher than the low A to the next A (and that top note is barely audible, mostly sounds like wind). Is it just too small? Or maybe I don't know how to play an ocarina :P
comments.author: IonPunk

comments.text: I'm betting it's the design, not you. :-)
comments.author: IonPunk

comments.text: I just did a print of the soprano version. Took about 2 hours. Also came out very nicely. Unfortunately, this one won't sound at all without several holes covered, and requires a very careful breath on the borderline. With all holes covered it produces a very nice loud sound, covering about a 3 node range (by ear, not measured) with breath variation.
comments.author: sludtke42

comments.text: Thank you for printing these!
comments.author: sludtke42

comments.text: Was a surprisingly easy print, though your support didn't come through, and I had to add some for the mouthpiece. Makes a nice tone very easily with minimal tendency to 'whistle'. I confess I don't have a lot of Ocarina experience, but the frequency varies quite widely with breath intensity. A soft blow with all holes covered yields 360 hz, gradually increasing to 440 with moderately strong breath.
comments.author: sludtke42

comments.text: Thanks for doing this!
comments.author: sludtke42

comments.text: Too big to make on my kossel :( Can you make a mini version?
comments.author: IonPunk

comments.text: What are the dimensions of your kossel?
comments.author: IonPunk

comments.text: I have a 150mm radius. Is there any way to figure out what ratio to scale it so it would still be in tune?
comments.author: budney

comments.text: I'm having a crack at it now: I'm using a genetic algorithm to find the best parameters, and I've restarted it with a base note of A5=880 Hz instead of A4=440 Hz. That should reduce the volume by roughly half (which won't be the same result as scaling this ocarina by 50%, because volume is cubed).
comments.author: IonPunk

comments.text: If you give me the difference in volume that is needed, I can probably calculate the ratio to scale it.
comments.author: budney

comments.text: OK, I've uploaded another STL file. The one labeled "soprano" is an octave higher, and only 100mm instead of 163mm in the longest dimension. Please let me know how it turns out!
comments.author: IonPunk

comments.text: Awesome! Thanks. I will print as soon as I can. I had a hotend clog (first one) and unclogged it just fine, but I snapped my thermistor wire...... Been trying for hours to solder it back together but it just won't work. I think the heat is melting the solder...

My mother wanted cabinet knobs for her kitchen that had an industrial/steampunk sort of feel, but didn't find anything suitable at the normal retail stores. She asked me if I could print up some industrial-looking gears which could be mounted on the cabinets, and this is the result.

Rather than screw them in from behind like normal knobs, these are meant to be mounted from the front so as not to put so much stress on the plastic when pulled. Simply use a suitably long wood screw to go through the knob and into the face of the drawer/cabinet.

I recently got the "4WD Arduino Compatible Mobile Platform" and was looking to put some sensors on it. I had some PING))) distance sensors that I want to put to use, so off to FreeCAD we go. A few hours and a lot of fiddling.
This model went nearly from print to picture. The PING slotted right in. The mounting holes needed drilling to the proper size. For me, a few twists by hand with the dremel and 3mm bit. Holes on the base are spaced to allow mounting in the appropriate spots on the platform, and to firmly mount the sensor.

Print and use.
The sensor is a Parallax PING))) ultrasonic sensor.
Mine is a 2005 Rev.A.
Take care the first time you put the sensor in the mount. I made special care for the mount not to bump or dislodge any of the surface mount components on the back.
Tolerances are tight though, and your print settings will affect your output.

author: GestoPlastico

title: Parametric Drill Guide for Z-axis Pipes Mostly Printed CNC

description.text:
8/5/2017 Update
I made Wall thickness & Base Thickness separate variables & fixed one bug.

This was designed to be used for the Mostly Printed CNC project, but could be used for probably any round pipe you want to drill perpendicular holes in. This made my job of drilling these pipes very easy. I used a 9/64" Drill bit for the holes. With a little more work on the openscad file, it could be adjusted to drill other angle holes in pipe. I did 2 sets of test prints on this, 1st one I used 24mm for the OD (U.S. version) of the pipe & the 2nd I used 23.7mm. 24mm was little too loose & 23.7 was a little too tight when putting both halfs together. I ended up using 1 side of 24mm & 1 side of 23.7mm to clamp nicely. 23.8mm is probably a better number to use for the OD of the pipe. Since I had printed this twice, I used the spare one to lay the other end of the pipe on. I realized after the fact, that I needed a place in the center of the jig to clamp to, but just used a small piece of wood over that open area. I changed the openscad file to give you an option of center clamp width. It will take you more time to clamp it all down than it will to actually drill the pipe.

I included the stl files for the standard 76.2mm hole spacing.

You can also open this with Thingiverse Customizer just like the Parametric Nut Trap I made. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:907882

I updated this later the same day to rev4 for the openscad file to tweak the code a little for consistency if the user changed the bolt holes to much larger sizes. I did not update the sample stl files though as the hole patterns are the same.

Print 2 halves for your intended hole spacing. You might also want to print another half for the other end of the pipe to lay flat on.

I used 5mm for the thickness of the base as I wanted to make sure the drill bit was perpendicular before going into the pipe. I would rather use a little more plastic & than to have to re-drill the pipe.

comments.text: have you got one for 25mm
comments.author: davidwhitt46

comments.text: Open this in the customizer & change the variable OD to 25.4 for 25mm pipe.  I used .4mm larger than the OD for a better fit.  Then change any of the other variables you want.  There are so many different possibilities for hole spacing, I did not make a STL file for each pipe size.

title: Deep Water Horizon Location in the Gulf

description.text:
This is a map of the sea floor showing the area around the Deep Water Horizon when the spill occurred. It is a big file I know but, I had the resolution and I wanted to get some of the coast in the data for the map. They were drilling at 5100 feet below sea level. The deepest part of the this map SE of the drill site is about 6700 feet. The stats are:
Vertical Amplification Factor: 8.0 (for better perspective)
Total Area (approximate): 6238.2 Sq. Kilometers (84.9 km X 73.5 km)

Map Coordinates:
LL: 28.598/-89.050
LR: 28.598/-89.918
UR: 29.262/-89.918
UL: 29.262/-89.050

STL is about 3.3 million polygons

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I used to get warping using PLA and it got bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. Now that I have a heated bed, I get much better results.

description.text:
EDIT: Extruder temperature stability improved using PID control. Also I slowed down the encoder knob in the menus

This is an unofficial firmware for BQs Prusa i3 Hephestos.
I got tired of having to go through 8 sub-menus to change filament or move steppers, so I ported the official Marlin firmware to Repetier.
Repetiers biggest advantage are its menus and settings. You can change temperature, fan speed and flow during prints.
Also the movements should be smoother than with Marlin but I have to do some more testing to confirm this.

Installation: Open Repetier.ino and upload using ArduinoIDE

You can use the Configuration.h to modify the firmware on this website:
http://www.repetier.com/firmware/v092/index.html

DISCLAIMER: Use at your own risk! I am not reponsible for any damage to your printer.

description.text:
A rigid-wing sailboat for both the #MakeItFloat and #CatchTheWind challenges.

A modern sailboat doesn't catch the wind, so much as flies through it. The sail acts like a wing, producing forward thrust air pressure acting on the sail and keel rather than the simply pushing the sail. As a result a modern yacht can travel faster than the wind!

Source repository and more information at https://chiselapp.com/user/mwm/repository/SailBoat/

description.text: rescale to 0.4 to be lego compatibele
Lets you create an escape board for your beehive.

This is used to create a bee escape board. The edging on your board needs to be about 1/2" (12 mm) so that the bee escape doesn't rest on the hive box below it. It's your choice for how to use it. Four of them can be printed and positioned in the center of your board to create an 8-way round bee escape. Or, you can put them in the corners of the board. For my bee escape board, I printed four of them and put one in each corner.

  • 8-way round bee escape - Cut a 3 to 4 inch hole in the center of your board. Center the four escapes over the hole and attach the escapes to the bottom of the escape board with screws.

  • Corner Escape - Cut a hole in each corner of your escape board where you are attaching an escape. Attach the escape with a screw.

To use the board, place it facing down beneath the honey super in your hive. After a day or two, most of the bees should have left out of the the honey super and will be unable to find their way back into it.

NOTE: I probably won't give this a try until September so I don't know how well it works.

description.text:
After several attempts to control the surface tension, finally I have a system that works properly ti print on 100,75,50,35,20,10 microns.
This system can be found only on hi end professional printers as Ultra by EnvisionTec.

Forget the problems caused by surface tension, such as bulging effect and others.

This vat are made of 3mm and 6mm transparent and white acrylic.
Barrels are made of 8mm. stainless steel.
Construcion plataform its made on 5mm aluminum.
Other hardware are printed on FFF printer on PLA filament.

Only require drilling 4 holes in your printer to assemble the entire system.

The self-adhesive film with teflon for the vat cap, I bought to guys of Muve3D .
http://www.muve3d.net/press/product/fepteflon-non-stick-reservoir-coating/

They have an instruction of how to put it correctly

I leave here the link for you to download the original file. It is made on Rhinoceros but leave a copy with .dwg extention.
So you can measure all the elements to determine where to make the holes on the back of your printer.

https://www.dropbox.com/s/353abkm3goq1w7s/NEW%20SYSTEM.rar?dl=0

http://youtu.be/WGl24ju_1yo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vRaSqutYaf8&feature=youtu.be

title: beefier Y frame for the Makerfarm 12" Prusa i3v

description.text:
This is a modification of Geodaves 12" frame. I had some issues with bed travel limits using the tensioner. I redesigned without the tesioner and added some supports to prevent warping when you get the belt tight. I also added some sorbothane vibration isolator mounts.

tested and works!

7/5/15 UPDATE. Made the mount a little wider to match the original specs of the frame. Previous model left the wheels a little sloppy in when the bed was all the way forward.
Also added a nut trap and countersunk the i3v logo some more.

title: Vitamin bottle cap with day arrow

description.text:
This cap is intended to be child-resistant (push down and twist to open) but I haven't verified that it meets any standards for child-resistant packaging. It has an arrow that snaps into one of seven positions to track the next day my daughter gets vitamins. I pulled the wax-paper gasket out of the original cap and put it in this one to form an airtight seal with the bottle neck.

The cap should fit any M53SP400-threaded bottle.

The cap is made of two pieces: an interior piece with threads, and an exterior piece with knurls. The pieces must be printed together (unless you're printing in a very flexible material), so you'll want to print with retraction enabled and with settings that handle overhangs decently. It'll probably still sound and feel rough.

I modeled it in Onshape. You can take a look at the model here. Feel free to adapt it to your needs.

Since Onshape doesn't have a text tool or a way to import 2D shapes for extrusion (as of this writing), I ended up printing a sticky label and cutting it to shape on my sister's Silhouette Cameo (a CNC paper cutter). I've attached an SVG file of a label similar to the one I printed.

Print cap file with printer settings optimized for retraction and overhangs.

Print arrow in a contrasting color. Snap onto top of cap.

Print label on sticky label and cut to shape. Apply to top of cap.

Remove gasket from original bottle cap and stuff into new cap.

remixed_from.author: dintid
remixed_from.title: Ultius Universal Quick change Carriage for standard 15 outer diameter bearings.

description.text:
This carriage allows you to mount an E3Dv6 or in my case an E3D lite6 hotend to your tantillus.

You will have to sacrifice a little bit of X and Y for this though.
Final buildplate dimensions are X:70 Y:85 Z:100

I also added an experimental version with mounting points for X and Y endstops, but I havent printed this version yet.

UPDATE: I printed the first endstop version, but it doesnt reach the Axis-Ends, will improve soon!

Here it is in action https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cGKqbfPhd0k

Print with ABS in 0.2 layer height and around 30-40% infill. Make sure you have a layer fan, as this part has a huge bridge.

Once you finished printing, simply snap off the thin wall on the left.

Insert 2x M3 nuts into the carriage's nutlocks, insert the E3D and screw the locker part on with 2x M3x20 screws.

comments.text: Could you move the head holder to the left by about 3-4 mm. Because it does not fit

description.text: This is a handle I designed for standard keyhole saw blades. The handle I had was "Pistol-style" and I didn't llike it. Importantly, the first finger contour has a significant projection to prevent forward slippage. Hexagonal lanyard hole also works with pegboard hooks.

description.text:
This is a deckbox with living-hinge flap made out of 5mm birch plywood on the 60watt ULS laser at ATX Hackerspace.  
Fits 75+ sleeved Magic: The Gathering Cards

Put some wood in the laser, load up the file and cut away, settings and other considerations will vary by machine/materials.  
On the 60 watt ULS at ATX hackerspace with the 5mm birch plywood I used Speed: 2.5%, Power 90% for the cuts and Speed 100%, Power: 65% for the etched logo.  
To finish it, I just lightly sanded all the pieces, drilled a hole in the flap and the front piece of the box for magnets to close and then glued everything together with woodglue. I ended up adding a washer to the magnet at the front as well to improve the closing strength and to make a nice Clack! when you close it.

description.text:
When I take my terrace/Cafe chair onto the lawn, the narrow steel tube leg sink into the grass. So I made some feet that stop that.

And my table wobbles when on the terrase so I made http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:919608 to fix that.

I suspect chairs have differnet diameters, and the angle between leg and ground varies, so I only publish the openSCAD file. Adjust diameter and angle to suit.

For the 3D print I used the coarsest and fastet print.
